title: Follow-up of Asymmetric Hearing Loss Post-Gamma Knife Radiation
chief_complaint: I am here for a follow-up to check if my hearing has changed. I do very well with my hearing aids, even when traveling on bus trips.

problem_summary.course: Stable; unchanged since last test in 2012.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: History of right vestibular schwannoma treated with gamma knife radiation.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Patient reports doing very well with current amplification (BiCROS).

history.present_illness: Patient presents for routine follow-up. She has a history of asymmetric hearing loss following gamma knife radiation for a right vestibular schwannoma in 2002.
history.otologic_history: Right vestibular schwannoma (treated 2002). Last hearing test was in 2012.
history.prior_management: Currently uses left BiCROS amplification (hearing aid on left, transmitter on right).

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Mild sloping to moderate SNHL (250-500 Hz), sloping/rising to severe/moderately severe (750-3000 Hz), sloping to severe (4000-8000 Hz). Left ear: Normal (250-500 Hz), sloping to slight/mild SNHL (1000-4000 Hz), sloping to moderately severe (6000-8000 Hz).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear speech testing was not measured (DNT). Left ear SRT was in agreement with PTA; WRS revealed normal ability to recognize speech.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Immittance testing was not measured at this visit.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient exhibits a stable, asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss. The right ear presents with a severe degree of loss (PTA 67 dB HL) and no measurable speech recognition, consistent with the history of vestibular schwannoma treatment. The left ear shows normal low-frequency hearing sloping to a high-frequency sensorineural loss with excellent speech recognition (96%). Findings are unchanged from 2012.
counseling_points: Your hearing has remained stable since your last test in 2012.
The BiCROS hearing aid system is the appropriate choice for your type of hearing loss, and I am glad to hear it is working well for you, even during travel.
We will schedule you for an annual hearing test to continue monitoring your hearing sensitivity.
Please follow up with your ENT specialist as scheduled.
notes_for_actor: Portray a satisfied patient who is accustomed to her hearing loss and manages well with her devices.
Emphasize that you travel by bus frequently and the hearing aids work well in that noisy environment.
You are not anxious; this is a routine check-up.
